Award.AwardTitle: Comparative microbial genomics -- beyond the genes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Georgia is awarded a grant to investigate the significance of microbial genome features beyond the protein-coding and RNA-coding genes. Standard computational analyses of genomes center on genes and gene content, whereas the availability of software to analyze other genomic features is limited. Investigating the full range of genomic features is important to understand the mechanisms of genome evolution and function. Genome features of interest include global and local characteristics. Global features range from very simple, such as G+C content, through species-specific preferences in codon usage, amino acid usage, and oligonucleotide composition, to cryptic periodic signals related to DNA curvature and nucleoid structure. Local features include, for example, specific sequence motifs and repeat structures (e.g., simple sequence repeats, palindromes, close repeats, or various types of short dispersed repeats), sequence patterns that can promote unusual DNA conformations (e.g., Z-DNA, H-DNA, G-DNA), or sequences that locally affect physical characteristics of DNA or RNA molecules (e.g., stability, curvature). Direct evidence of biological significance of these genome features is scarce. With limited experimental options, the detection of biologically significant genomic features often relies on statistical methods. Computational tools will be designed for analyses of these features in microbial genomes, and subsequently these tools will be applied in systematic examination of prokaryotic genomes. Comparative genomic approaches will be used for initial validation of the results obtained by statistical analyses of individual genomes and some of the specific hypotheses will be verified by experiments. The data ensuing from the comparative analyses of microbial genomes will be available to other researchers and can be utilized in interpretations of experimental data and design of future experiments.

A significant part of this project is devoted to enhancing research infrastructure by developing new computational methods, algorithms and tools for analyses and comparisons of microbial genomes. The new software will be distributed under the terms of the GNU General Public License, which allows anyone to use and modify the software without restrictions. In addition to making software available for download, interactive user interfaces will be developed and combined in an online environment for analysis of prokaryotic genomes. Software developed in this project will be used in courses and workshops. Undergraduate and high school students will be recruited to participate in the research. This effort includes a new student-parent summer program, where high school or undergraduate students will execute a research project together with a parent or other relative. Furthur information about this project and its software may be found at the PI's lab website at http://www.cmbl.uga.edu/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Properties of living organisms are largely determined by their genetic makeup, which consists of protein- and RNA-coding genes, regulatory elements, and other characteristics of the organisms’ genomes. This project was aimed at gaining new insights into the importance of various genomic elements in prokaryotes with emphasis on genome properties other than protein- and RNA-coding genes. Part of this work included development of new methodologies and software for analyses of genomic DNA sequences.

A novel set of software tools, called PerPlot and PerScan, was developed for analysis of 10-11 base pair (bp) periodicity in DNA sequences that is related to intrinsically curved DNA. Extensive analysis of prokaryotic chromosomes, plasmids, and bacteriophages suggests that curved DNA plays dual roles in prokaryotic cells. Apart from often being found in regulatory elements, intrinsically curved DNA contributes to folding of the chromosome in the cell. Moreover, persistent DNA curvature-related sequence periodicity throughout the genome appears to help protect the chromosome from integration of foreign DNA.

A survey of sequence patterns that promote formation of unusual DNA conformations was performed in >1000 genomes. A new statistical methodology was developed to determine whether a particular type of sequence pattern or DNA conformation was utilized more or less frequently than expected by chance. The results explained some anomalies previously reported by other authors and showed significant differences in structural properties of chromosomes of organisms living in different environments, in particular with respect to optimal growth temperature.

Several novel software tools were developed in the course of this project. In addition to the abovementioned PerPlot and PerScan programs for analysis of DNA curvature-related sequence periodicity, a package of tools for analysis of high-throughput sequencing data of transposon mutants, Tn-seq Explorer, was released. Another software package combining analysis of ChIP-chip data with regulatory motif-finding in DNA sequences will be released within a few months. These and other software tools developed in our laboratory are accessible to researchers as well as general public at our web site http://www.cmbl.uga.edu/software.html, which also offers our research datasets for download.

The funded research provided training opportunities for several students, including five graduate students, five undergraduate students, and three high school students. The interdisciplinary character of our research naturally promotes interactions of students from different fields, including bioinformatics, statistics, computer science, and microbiology. All students participating in this research, including the high school students, worked on independent projects and made significant contributions to the research outcomes. Two graduate and two undergraduate students presented their work at local symposia and one of the undergraduate students received a reward for a best student presentation.
